statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Colorado 79, Kansas State 75
article.story: BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Chris Copeland had struggled to find his scoring touch in his previous two games. He insisted the 11 points in those games weren't serious. "Nothing that some rest and quality time with the trainer couldn't handle," the Colorado senior forward said. "I had some soreness in my knees, I was a bit grounded, but nothing serious." On Saturday night, Copeland scored 17 points, including 14 in the second half, and Richard Roby had 18 as Colorado won its fifth straight conference game by beating Kansas State 79-75 Saturday night. "It was just my night," Copeland said. "I got my knees under me and some things clicked on for me." Copeland was 5-for-10 shooting in the second half. Roby was held in check most of the game before finishing 7-for-12 for Colorado (15-3, 5-2 Big 12). "There are times when he thinks he is Magic (Johnson) and times we think he is tragic," Colorado coach Ricardo Patton said of Copeland. "Tonight, he came around." The Buffaloes last won five straight conference games in the 1996-97 season. Colorado point guard Marcus Hall collapsed, suffering from lower back spasms with 2:02 left in the game. He was carried off the court on a stretcher. The injury was later updated to a lower lumbar strain by school officials. Cartier Martin led Kansas State (12-5, 3-3) with 24 points. Lance Harris had 23 for the Wildcats, who had their three-game conference winning streak snapped. "We gave I don't know how many points away that were the result of not getting down the floor in time," Kansas State coach Jim Wooldridge said. "We didn't know who we were guarding at times, we worked an out of bounds play where they got a layup out of that and then we gave Copeland five points to start the second half." Copeland began finding the range early in the second half, hitting a pair of 3-pointers and a short jumper to put Colorado ahead 46-41. Martin, who had only six points at the half, and Harris hit 3-pointers to close the gap to 51-48 with 14:34 left. The Buffaloes tightened their defense and led 63-56 after Martane Freeman converted two free throws and a 3-point play with 9:26 left. Martin hit consecutive 3-pointers to get the Wildcats within 63-62 with 7:31 remaining. David Hoskins made it a one-point game, 65-64, but Roby had a layup after Copeland's layup and two free throws and Roby had another layup to give Colorado some breathing room and a 71-66 edge with 3:26 left. Freeman sealed it with two free throws with under a minute left. The game was tied at 35 at halftime after Kansas State rallied with an 18-7 surge in the last 7:36. Copeland's 3-pointer put Colorado ahead 27-18, and Freeman's 3-pointer made it 35-29 before a 3-pointer by David Hoskins and three-point play by Akeem Wright in the final 2:25 deadlocked the game. Kansas State finished 9-for-17 on 3-pointers, which Patton said caught his staff by surprise. "There was nothing on film that indicated they would take that many 3-pointers," Patton said. "They were primarily a penetrate and dish team."
